title: Wilson's Disease
icd10: G25.5 (Other chorea — for movement disorder presentation)
G25.2 (Other specified forms of tremor — for tremor-predominant presentation)
F06.8 (Other specified mental disorders due to known physiological condition — psychiatric presentation)
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of Wilson's disease in adolescents and adults presenting with neurologic, hepatic, or psychiatric manifestations. Covers diagnostic workup (ceruloplasmin, 24-hour urine copper, slit-lamp exam, hepatic copper, genetic testing), chelation therapy (D-penicillamine, trientine), zinc maintenance therapy, liver transplant evaluation, symptomatic management of neurological symptoms (dystonia, tremor, parkinsonism, psychiatric), and family screening. Excludes other copper metabolism disorders (Menkes disease), isolated non-Wilson hepatic cirrhosis, and drug-induced movement disorders.

Essential/Core Labs.target: <20 mg/dL (often <10 mg/dL in WD); normal does NOT exclude WD

All neurologic WD; movement disorder management, monitoring for chelation-related worsening
Dystonia, tremor, parkinsonism management; botulinum toxin injections
ALL suspected WD — Kayser-Fleischer ring assessment; sunflower cataract screening
ATP7B testing confirmation, family screening, reproductive counseling
Fulminant hepatic failure, decompensated cirrhosis, New Wilson Index ≥11
Depression, psychosis, personality change, behavioral disturbance (common in WD)

Patient Instructions.item: Wilson's disease is a lifelong condition requiring CONTINUOUS treatment — never stop chelation or zinc without physician guidance
Take chelation medication (penicillamine or trientine) on an EMPTY STOMACH — 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals
If taking zinc, separate from chelator by at least 2 hours; take zinc between meals
Return to ED if: worsening jaundice, confusion, vomiting blood, black stools, new neurologic symptoms, worsening speech or swallowing, severe abdominal pain
Report ANY new neurologic symptoms during the first 2-3 months of chelation (worsening is possible and requires dose adjustment)
Avoid HIGH-COPPER FOODS during initial treatment: liver/organ meats, shellfish (especially lobster, oysters), chocolate, mushrooms, nuts, dried fruits, soy products
Avoid drinking water through copper pipes (consider water testing; use filter or bottled water if copper pipes present)
Alcohol is STRICTLY prohibited — causes additional liver damage
Women of childbearing age: pregnancy requires switching from chelator to zinc (chelators are teratogenic); discuss family planning with physician BEFORE conception
ALL first-degree relatives (siblings, children, parents) MUST be screened for Wilson's disease — siblings have 25% risk
Carry a medical alert card/bracelet indicating Wilson's disease and current medications
Regular follow-up is ESSENTIAL — blood and urine tests needed every 3-6 months lifelong

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Low-copper diet during initial decoppering phase (avoid >1 mg copper/day); can liberalize slightly once stable on treatment
Regular exercise as tolerated; may improve dystonia and mood
Smoking cessation (impairs liver function and overall health)
Hepatitis A and B vaccination if not immune (protect remaining liver function)
Avoid hepatotoxic medications (acetaminophen limit <2 g/day; avoid NSAIDs if cirrhotic; avoid statins if decompensated)
Genetic counseling for reproductive planning; autosomal recessive — both parents are carriers; 25% risk for each sibling
Mental health support; depression and anxiety are common and treatable components of WD
Screen all first-degree relatives: ceruloplasmin, 24h urine copper, LFTs, slit-lamp exam, ATP7B genetic testing
